title: 112_s965
content: The "Family Act of 2011" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings related to families. The "Family Act of 2011" is also known as the Family Act. It highlights the recognition of infertility as a disease by the World Health Organization and the lack of consistent medical insurance coverage for infertility treatments at the State level. Only 8 States have laws requiring comprehensive infertility coverage, leading to limited coverage for treatments like in vitro fertilization. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR CERTAIN INFERTILITY TREATMENTS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section providing a credit for specific infertility treatments. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible individuals a tax credit of 50% of qualified infertility treatment expenses, up to a limit of $13,360 per year. The credit is reduced for individuals with adjusted gross income over $150,000. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is reduced for individuals with adjusted gross income over $150,000. Adjusted gross income is determined without regard to certain sections. No credit is allowed if a deduction or credit is taken elsewhere, if reimbursement is received, or if insurance reimburses the expense. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is limited based on income and insurance reimbursement. The credit amount cannot exceed the regular tax liability plus other allowable credits for the taxable year. Unused credits can be carried forward in certain cases. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is subject to limitations based on income and insurance reimbursement. Excess credits can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year, with a maximum carryforward period of 5 years. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses can be carried forward for up to 5 years after the credit arose. Qualified infertility treatment expenses include in vitro fertilization administered by a licensed medical practitioner for a diagnosis of infertility. Expenses for fertility preservation procedures conducted before medical treatments can also qualify. Fertility preservation procedures conducted before medical procedures that may cause infertility are considered qualified infertility treatment expenses. Infertility is defined as the inability to conceive or carry a pregnancy to live birth, excluding infertility resulting from procedures designed for sterilization. Eligible individuals are those seeking infertility treatment. Eligible individuals for infertility treatment must be diagnosed by a licensed physician in the United States. Married taxpayers must file joint returns, and adjustments for inflation apply to dollar limitations for taxable years after December 31, 2012. The taxable year begins with adjustments for inflation, rounding amounts to the nearest multiple of $10. Income limitations increase based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. Conforming amendments are made to the table of sections. The taxable year starts with adjustments for inflation, rounding amounts to the nearest multiple of $10. Conforming amendments are made to the table of sections. Sec. 23A allows for a credit for certain infertility treatments. Various sections of the Code are amended to include references to Sec. 23A. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011.
